Hi all,

I have privately shared the 2 tsuba that spawned my
Mito questions with Jim and Cary.  Cary suggested it
would be best to submit these in Japan and it got me
thinking about many questions surrounding this
process.  I don't recall a lot of discussion around
fittings submission, but there have been many
discussions on submiting swords. So I thought it would
be helpful (for at least some of us or at least me).
1.  When is it worth submitting fittings to shinsa?  I
understand the value of knowledge but aren't fees a
little high for fittings in relation to swords? 
2. Is the process similiar to swords, must submit
several times for higher papers? 
2.  What criteria would you use? for example, price: a
$250 tsuba may not but a $500 would? or age a late edo
piece isn't worth it?
3.  A sword with papers usually increases value (often
greatly(?)).  How much would this apply to tsuba
and/or fittings in general?
4. What kind of conditions must your tsuba be in for a
real consideration? patina, rust, missing inlay, etc? 
5. Does age factor into condition, ie koto swords may
have certain flaws overlooked in the papering process
but shinto would not, does this translate over to
tsuba?

All comments are appreciated.  By the way, the 2 tsuba
I was questioning are located in the other yahoo list
folder under mantis (I think labeled "11 &1") which
were recently shared with on that list.  Anyone else
interested I will gladly send pics of.  

Thank you
Ken
